column5: Pros:Price versus performance, this chip represents great value. I purchased one on Black Friday after sitting out AMD processors since 2012. column5: Pros:Price versus performance, this chip represents great value. I purchased one on Black Friday after sitting out AMD processors since 2012. It will not be faster framerate-wise compared to the fastest Intel chips but then again, it is  not as expensive either. What I look for in gaming, is the deviation between minimum and maximum frames per second. That is usually an indicator as to if you'll enjoy smooth gameplay. This CPU crushes it in that regard. It is 'glass' smooth in everything I've used it for to date. Encoding video is another area where it excels. I encoded an 89 GB video a few nights ago with this CPU and it did it in way less time than the I7-7700K and was almost as fast as the I7-8800K.
column6: Cons:Would have liked to see it offered with a choice of the Prism cooler as an option... just to have a bit more overhead on default cooling.Not a big deal as most will change the stock 'though-very-good' cooler anyway for something more exotic.
column7: Other Thoughts:I'd certainly recommend it to others and I am happy with the purchase after this much time away from AMD processors.

column3: If you want the best performance make sure you buy ram matching your processor base clock or close to it.
column5: Pros:Processor is fast, much better than my already decent Intel 6600K processors in video production and games.For video ripping and rendering the 2600X is as fast as my 5930K processor which cost hundreds more. Games seem like they play faster, or have less drops below 60 at 1440P when compared to my 6600K. Mafia 3 city no longer chugs and skips when riding at through certain parts of the game, and probably adds 5 FPS when compared to my 6600K processor.In terms of gaming performance the 2600X performs at Intel's non K 6700 Sky Lake based processors which is certainly not bad. It can beat the 7600 and 7700K processors in some games, but overall their base clock and IPC advantage is too much for this miracle processor.
column6: Cons:- You need fast ram to take advantage of this processor. Ryzen's Infinity Fabric runs at the same clock speed as your ram. I found paring my AMD 2600X with ram running at it's base close or DDR 3600 produced better results than DDR 4 at 2400, and 2666.- On my Asus motherboard you can't run above DDR 2400 if all four memory slots occupied. Annoying, but I needed to upgrade my ram anyway as DDR 4 at 2666 mhz was limiting my 2600X performance by maybe 15%.- If you love overclocking don't waste your time as this processor can't overclock much, and the performance gains is usually less than 5%. I mean you get two more FPS, but that's about it. I was able to get it stable at just 4.2 GHZ on all cores, but AMD precision boost was able to hit 4.25 ghz on all cores stable so it works a little better than my manual results.- Lastly the cooler that comes with it is garbage as my processor would hit 80 degrees C often. Upgrading to the 2700X wraith prism cooler lowered my max temp down to 67 without the OC, and 71 C. with the 4.2 GHZ OC.
column7: Other Thoughts:- If you're looking for a high performance rendering station for under $1000 built this is the the CPU for you.- If you're a gamer only you might be better off going with Intel's 8600 CPU as it's measurably faster in most games. In terms of game performance the 2600X performance is about as good as Intel's 6700 or 7600K processors so you can definitely game on it.- You need memory running at the CPU base clock to advantage of the processor, a real budget killer at DDR 4 3600. DDR 3200 with extremely fast timing would net your good performance as well.- I highly recommend this processor, just make sure you have fast ram, and a decent cooler as this processor loves memory bandwidth.

column1: AMD RYZEN 5 2600 6-Core 3.4 GHz (3.9 GHz Max Boost) Socket AM4 65W YD2600BBAFBOX Desktop Processor
column3: First AMD build since the Phenom II days
column5: Pros:Lot of cores/threads for the money!Low power draw/good tempsStrong IPCXFR 2 is actually worthwhileA stock cooler included that isn't worthless!
column6: Cons:CCX design introduces latency relative to IntelNot quite as strong at gaming as the competitionMemory compatibility and speeds are still an issue, though its better nowInfinity Fabric interconnect VERY sensitive to said RAM speeds, and RAM is $$$$$$ these daysPerformance improvements over first gen Ryzen are negligible overall, because this still IS first gen Ryzen with some mild tweaks
column7: Other Thoughts:Coming from an i5-4670K, this CPU doesn't exactly offer earth shattering improvements for my uses at gaming and common tasks.  I was gonna wait for "Zen 2" coming next year, but an unplanned event forced my hand.  Since I primarily game, the numbers would point out that I needed to buy an Intel Coffee Lake CPU, but I'm a little weary of Intel's grip on the CPU market and the resulting complacency.The performance advantage Intel currently has is MUCH smaller than it was when I built my last PC in 2013.  Haswell completely crushed all of the Bulldozer/Piledriver FX chips across the board, which is how I ended up with an i5.  Things have changed.  Intel's IPC advantage is small (`10% at best) and frequencies are respectable for Ryzen , though Intel still has a sizable advantage there as CL CPUs have a much higher clock ceiling.  Toss in the fact I'm gaming at 1440P, and the performance between AMD/Intel is pretty much on par with each other.  Plus, for "i5" money, you're getting 6 cores/12 threads versus 6 cores/6 threads on the Intel side of things.  No, those extra threads don't do much for gaming at this time, but having that extra compute grunt is not at all a bad thing.AMD has finally gotten off their lazy backsides and re-introduced actual competition to the space!  Coffee Lake is for sure a competent competitor, but that's the point, isn't it?  One last positive point to make is the AM4 socket and chipsets for Ryzen CPUs will remain viable until at least 2020 according to AMD.  If Zen 2 comes out and cranks it out of the park with 7 nm and an overhaul of the Zen uArch, all one has to do is purchase the new CPU, perform a BIOS update on their current board, take out previous CPU and drop in new one!  This is something Intel has not been good with at all, even when their socket remains unchanged.  They'll just "require" a new chipset, so current board owners are out of luck.  Having an upgrade path is nice.All in all, a great value and beastly CPU for gaming, production, and everything else.  Definitely worthy of consideration for anyone looking at a new build.

column1: AMD RYZEN 5 2600 6-Core 3.4 GHz (3.9 GHz Max Boost) Socket AM4 65W YD2600BBAFBOX Desktop Processor
column5: Pros:I purchased the Ryzen 5 2600 as part of an upgrade for my aging Phenom II X4 960T computer. I was trying stay in the $300-$400 dollar range for this upgrade, which ended up including the Asrock X370 PRO4 motherboard and Crucial's Ballistix Sport DDR4-2400 (2x4GB kit). I had originally been looking at the Ryzen 5 1600, but the recent availability of the Ryzen 5 2000 CPUs tempted me into taking advantage of their modest improvements. I also considered Intel's 6 core, i5-8600K, but the Intel solution pushed my budget envelope even more. (Beyond the cost of the processor itself, the Intel motherboards tended to be more expensive, and a third party heatsink was required.)Despite the 2600 running at about the same speed of my 960T (the 960T was overclocked to 3 .8 GHz when running four cores and 3.6 GHz when running 6 cores), I estimate that the 2600 delivers close to 50% more computing power than the 960T. World of Tanks, for example, had been CPU bottlenecked by the 960T, but that is no longer the case with the Ryzen 5 2600.Although the 2600 chip is capable of 3.9 GHz boost speeds, I more typically see long-term boost speeds of 3.65 GHz while playing WoT, for example. More importantly, this processor is doing a much better job of balancing workloads across cores. The 960T tended to bottleneck WoT, in large part, because it had one core running at 100%. The 2600 does a much better job of using all available cores.I experienced no difficulty running this CPU on a X370 motherboard (that came with a "2000 ready" BIOS installed).
column6: Cons:The weakest aspect to the 2600 retail package is the Wraith Stealth heatsink. This cooler consists of a 90 mm fan mounted on top of a round aluminum heatsink that stands only 20 mm tall  (about 3/4 of an inch, not counting the fan). Part of the disappointment is that this is a step down from the Wraith Spire cooler, which the Ryzen 5 1600 comes with. The Stealth cooler is adequate for everyday use. (For example, while playing WoT, which only uses about 30% of the CPU's capacity, the temperatures were around 60-65 deg. C.) However under more intense workload, such as Prime95, the temperatures were up close to 80 deg. C. This high temperature is not enough to cause thermal throttling, but it made me uncomfortable. I suspect that other heavy workloads, such as a video encoding project, would lead to high tempertures, as well. It probably could go without saying (as it is generally true for all stock heatsinks), but I would not use this heatsink for overclocking and certainly not at voltages beyond the default setting.

column6: Cons:Not really the SSD's fault  but this and all other NVME SSD's are not Windows 7 friendly, as some negative reviewers realize too late. It's not plug and play at all unlike Windows 10 (a fresh install attempt from a DVD will simply result in W7 not seeing the SSD to install to), but where there's a will there's a way. My fix was to simply install W7 to a plain SATA3 HDD and install all the latest patches and updates (the DVD version is missing NVMe drivers that were added 5 years after initial release) and name that drive BOOT1. Install/update W7 again to a 2nd HDD and name that BOOT2. Now log into BOOT2 (via bios option) and the NVME should be visible in disk management. Initialize/format it and then Copy/paste Boot1 to the NVMe, shut down, remove the now-unneeded HDD's (I use them for disaster recovery if for some reason I need to reinstall OS, less updates and apps to reinstall), go into bios and set NVME as first boot option, restart, done. A bit more effort than simply installing once from a thumb drive but worth not having to put up with W10's cr@p.

column5: Pros:If there is one thing I want people to know about this drive, is that size matters!  It is not plainly visible, but you will NOT get the advertised speeds with the 250GB or the 500GB version. See the Cons for more on this.The WD Black NVMe drive is a very impressive drive in terms of speed.  Even with the 250GB model, I achieved sequential speeds of +3000MB/s read and +1600MB/s write.  Do note though that these benchmarks are under the best conditions possible.  In my tests, they are not formatted and the test is performed on raw storage with no AV scanners turned on.  Nothing but the test interacts with the drive.  So while you may see lower performance in normal use, these numbers will give you a ballpark estimate.Installation was fairly simple.  My motherboard needed to have a few heatsinks removed to expose the M.2 slot I wanted to use.  Once removed, simply insert the drive in the connector and screw it down.   NOTE: This drive does not come with installation hardware.  The needed hardware should have been included with your motherboard! Also make sure you have only the needed standoffs installed.  Remove any standoffs that are not used for mounting.Once installed, Windows 10 immediately picked up on the drive with no BIOS tweaks needed. Simply open the Disk Management tool and initialize/partition the drive and you are good to go.  If you are installing a fresh Windows onto the drive, it worked as it would any other drive.
column6: Cons:If you look at the "Specification Sheet" listed under the "Overview" tab, you find a table that shows the speeds for the various size of drives.  For the 250GB version, this is fairly significant write speed jump when compared to the 500GB model.  Below is a crude table of the information from the spec sheet:------------------250GB / 500GB / 1000GB:Seq. Read: 3000 / 3400 / 3400MB/sSeq. Write: 1600 / 2500 / 2800MB/sWhen comparing the seq. write speed from the 250 to the advertised speeds, there is a difference of 1200MB/s!  I really feel WD could have done better to disclose this than simply saying "Speeds up to...".  This little detail they buried in the spec sheet is the only reason I have knocked off 1 egg.
column7: Other Thoughts:Overall, I think this is a great drive, but if you can manage the extra expense I would recommend the 500GB version for the improved write speed if nothing else.  If you don't care for the extra write speed, the 250GB model is pretty darn good too.  Make sure you have reviewed the motherboards manual for compatibility and resource availability.  If you are running multiple GPUs, you will want to know how the motherboard will handle the PCIe lanes as many times the secondary PCI express slot for GPUs will share PIC express lanes with the M.2 slot.  In other cases, the second M.2 slot may be limited on PCI express version or available lanes.CrystalDiskMark 6.0.0 x64 - 250GB model (Read/Write):Sequential - 3121.6 / 1608.3 MB/s4KiB Q8T8 - 638.5 / 555.4 MB/s4KiB Q32T1 - 637.5 / 483.4 MB/s4KiB Q1T1 - 49.7 / 174.2 MB/sSequential speeds are more descriptive of large file copies or any time consecutive data is read or written.The 4KiB readings are more descriptive of dealing with many small files.Test hardware:Windows 10.0.14393 (Standard NVM Express Controller driver v10.0.14393.0)Ryzen 5 2600XAsus ROG STRIX X470-X (BIOS 4011 - AGESA 1.0.0.2a + SMU 43.18)G.Skill TridentZ DDR4-3200 (Running at 3400MHz)

column5: Pros:The WD black NVMe 500 gig SSD arrived in an unremarkable black and white box. Please note the NVMe on the box.  This is quite important as you will read later on.  Inside was the drive itself in a 2 part plastic container and a fold out tech support and warranty paper in about a dozen languages. Nothing else was included.  Personally I think they should at least include that tiny screw that you use to install the drive since it’s always getting lost.Be aware that this is a newer version of a current WD m.2 drive.  As you’ll read below this is a much faster drive so look for the NVMe on the box.  There is absolutely no reason to buy the older drive unless you have a motherboard without a PCIe X4 socket or it’s on sale at a much reduced price.Installing the drive is about as easy as anything you can do to a motherboard… unless you don’t have the tiny screw and then you’re sc…..  But you get my drift.  The only thing you have to check is if you have a PCI-e X4 m2 slot.  The older your mother board the more likely you are not to have one. Check your motherboard manual or the Internet.  Remember… Google is your friend.The install of the WD Black NVMe the installation of Windows 10 Pro X64 went fine. There is no need to install a driver with this device.  I checked and the only downloads available were the SSD Dashboard and a copy of Acronis if you need to move your current Windows install to the new drive.  Since I was installing a fresh copy of windows I didn’t use the Acronis.  The SSD Dashboard however I did download and install. It gives you some helpful information.  It covers SSD temp, a pie chart for how much of the SSD is being used, an app for checking for firmware and an especially useful readout of what interface you are using.  Helpful for knowing why your speed may not be what’s advertised.  It does not handle manual trim so you’ll either have to count on Windows or download a utility like SSD Tweaker.I installed the WD Black SSD into the PCIe X4 socket on my test system which includes an ASUS Strix Z270G Gaming motherboard with a core i7 7700K processor and 16 gigs of memory.  It also has an MSI GeForce 1060.  This is my old production system that I’m reconditioning to sell.  That’s why I needed to install windows on this SSD.The WD Black NVMe SSD took everything I could throw at it in stride.  I played some Far Cry 5 at 2560 x 1440 and it ran between 40 and 50 FPS so I was happy. I got a crystal disk mark score of 3460 MB\s read and 2550 MB\s write which is just about the same as advertised on the box.  I’m only using the first box in Crystal Disk Mark.  It’s really only be used as a comparison so no need to fill up the space with lots of random figures.I had a 250 Gig Samsung 960 Evo in this machine and the Crystal Disk Mark scores were   3073 MB\s read and 1396 MB\s write.  This is a smaller drive so the scores will be lower so I’m going to say the Read marks were about even for the two.  The WD Black had a much higher write performance so maybe I’ll give the lead to it.I actually have one of the older WD Black m.2 ssds in my new production machine.  It has an ASUS Z370 motherboard and a core i7 8700K with 16 gigs of memory and an ASUS 1070 GTX video card.  The old 500 gig black SSD gives me crystal Disk mark scores of 1854 MB\s write and 773 MB\s write.  That is quite a difference from the new drive.
